intro: Verbesina sylvicola, commonly known as the woodland beggar-ticks, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in moist, wooded areas and has hairy stems and leaves. Its yellow flowers bloom in late summer, and the plant produces small, spiny fruits that aid in seed dispersal. Verbesina sylvicola is often found in rich, loamy soils and thrives in partial to full shade.
